title: Investigate evil-mode transient closing unexpectedly in graph view
description:
## Problem

Doom/evil-mode user reports that the graph transient menu closes unexpectedly when pressing C-z.

## Root Cause Found

**C-z conflict between evil-mode and transient.el:**
- Evil: C-z = `evil-toggle-key` (switch to/from emacs state)
- Transient: C-z = suspend transient for later resumption

When user presses C-z to toggle evil state, transient's C-z handler fires instead, suspending/closing the transient.

## User Report

> I am on doom and I'm having an issue with vim style keybindings vs the standard emacs keybindings. In order to navigate in the project graph area, I have Ctrl-Z to switch between the two states vim vs emacs and you need the emacs state to accomplish anything in the project graph. The issue is when I press the ? mark button, there is a state change to vim keys even if I have already switched to the emacs state and when I try to Ctrl-Z to switch back to emacs state the transient graph disappears.

## Partial Workaround

Adding to Doom config helps with initial entry (no more C-z needed):
```elisp
(after! evil
  (evil-set-initial-state 'org-gtd-graph-view-mode 'emacs))
```

But transient still closes when C-z is pressed.

## Potential Solutions

1. Set `org-gtd-graph-view-mode` to emacs state by default (avoid needing C-z)
2. User rebinds `evil-toggle-key` to something other than C-z
3. Unbind C-z from transient-map when our transients are active
4. Document the conflict and workaround

## References

- Transient manual: C-z suspends transients for later resumption
- Evil settings: evil-toggle-key defaults to C-z

## Relevant Files

- org-gtd-graph-mode.el (mode derived from special-mode)
- org-gtd-graph-transient.el (transient menu definitions)

title: Add 'actions' category to GTD view DSL
description: Single-action items (ORG_GTD=Actions) are missing from the DSL. Should be (category . actions) like other categories. Need to TDD add it and update documentation to make it one of the first examples.

title: Implement insert-after with one successor
description: Replace current add-child delegation. When selected has one successor: A→B becomes A→C→B. Remove A→B, add A→C and C→B dependencies.

title: Task 9: Update documentation
description: Update Commentary section in org-gtd-view-language.el with duration comparison syntax documentation

title: Implement insert-before with multiple predecessors
description: When selected task has multiple predecessors, prompt user to choose which parent to insert after. Only rewire that parent→selected edge to parent→new→selected. Leave other parents unchanged.

title: who filter not implemented in native agenda skip function
description:
## Problem

The `who` filter documented in org-gtd-view-language.el (line 80-81) is silently ignored when using native agenda blocks.

Example that doesn't work:
```elisp
((name . "Delegated to Alice")
 (type . delegated)
 (who . "Alice"))
```

The `who` filter only works for `stuck-delegated` type detection (checking for missing who), not for filtering to show items delegated to a specific person.

## Root Cause

`org-gtd-view-lang--build-skip-function` doesn't extract or handle the `who` filter.

The org-ql translation exists (`org-gtd-view-lang--translate-who-filter`, line 529) but native agenda blocks don't use it.

## Fix Required

1. Add `who` handling to `org-gtd-view-lang--build-skip-function`
2. Use `org-gtd-pred--property-equals` with the semantic :who property lookup
3. Add tests for who filtering with native blocks

title: Task 6: Handle when filter comparison expressions
description: Update when filter handling in org-gtd-view-lang--build-skip-function to support (< "14d"), (> "-7d"), (= "today") syntax

title: Implement org-gtd-view-show function
description: Add org-gtd-view-show function to provide clean DSL API for showing GTD views. Function should accept a view-spec and display it as an agenda. Eliminates boilerplate from user code.

title: todo filter not implemented in native agenda skip function
description:
## Problem

The `todo` filter documented in org-gtd-view-language.el (line 68) is silently ignored when using native agenda blocks.

Example that doesn't work:
```elisp
((name . "Specific TODO States")
 (todo . ("TODO" "NEXT")))
```

## Root Cause

`org-gtd-view-lang--build-skip-function` doesn't extract or handle the `todo` filter.

The org-ql translation exists (`org-gtd-view-lang--translate-todo-filter`, line 553) but native agenda blocks don't use it.

## Fix Required

1. Create `org-gtd-pred--todo-matches` predicate
2. Add `todo` handling to `org-gtd-view-lang--build-skip-function`
3. Add tests for todo filtering with native blocks

scheduled filter not implemented in native agenda skip function
description:
## Problem

The `scheduled` filter documented in org-gtd-view-language.el (lines 62-64) is silently ignored when using native agenda blocks.

Example that doesn't work:
```elisp
((name . "Overdue Scheduled")
 (scheduled . past))
```

## Root Cause

`org-gtd-view-lang--build-skip-function` doesn't extract or handle the `scheduled` filter.

The org-ql translation exists (`org-gtd-view-lang--translate-scheduled-filter`, line 480) but native agenda blocks don't use it.

## Fix Required

1. Create `org-gtd-pred--scheduled-matches` predicate (or use property-ts predicates with SCHEDULED)
2. Add `scheduled` handling to `org-gtd-view-lang--build-skip-function`
3. Add tests for scheduled filtering with native blocks

title: Tags filter not implemented in native agenda skip function
description:
## Problem

The `tags` filter documented in org-gtd-view-language.el (line 89) is silently ignored when using native agenda blocks. Items are shown regardless of their tags.

Example user configuration that doesn't work:
```elisp
((name . "One Hard Thing, Deep Work")
 (type . next-action)
 (tags . ("mediumenergy" "highenergy"))
 (effort . (> "0:59"))
 (priority . (A)))
```

Items with other tags like "someenergy" appear in the view where only "mediumenergy" and "highenergy" should appear.

## Root Cause

`org-gtd-view-lang--build-skip-function` (lines 987-1069) handles:
- ✅ type filter
- ✅ area-of-focus filter
- ✅ when filter
- ✅ priority filter
- ✅ effort filter
- ✅ clocked filter
- ✅ last-clocked-out filter
- ❌ **tags filter - NOT HANDLED**

The tags filter IS translated for org-ql (`org-gtd-view-lang--translate-tags-filter`, lines 557-559), but native agenda blocks use skip functions, and the skip function builder doesn't include tags.

## Fix Required

1. Create `org-gtd-pred--tags-matches` predicate in org-gtd-predicates.el
2. Add tags handling to `org-gtd-view-lang--build-skip-function`
3. Add tests for tags filtering with native blocks

## Additional Consideration

The org-ql semantics use OR matching: `(tags "a" "b")` matches items with ANY of those tags. If exclusive matching is needed (only items with those tags, excluding others), consider adding `tags-exclude` or `tags-only` filter semantics.

title: deadline filter not implemented in native agenda skip function
description:
## Problem

The `deadline` filter documented in org-gtd-view-language.el (line 61) is silently ignored when using native agenda blocks.

Example that doesn't work:
```elisp
((name . "Overdue Items")
 (type . project)
 (deadline . past))
```

## Root Cause

`org-gtd-view-lang--build-skip-function` doesn't extract or handle the `deadline` filter.

The org-ql translation exists (`org-gtd-view-lang--translate-deadline-filter`, line 473) but native agenda blocks don't use it.

## Fix Required

1. Create `org-gtd-pred--deadline-matches` predicate (or use property-ts predicates with DEADLINE)
2. Add `deadline` handling to `org-gtd-view-lang--build-skip-function`
3. Add tests for deadline filtering with native blocks

title: Create helper function to prioritize current project tasks in selection
notes:
Tests consistently fail with wrong ordering. All other graph transient tests PASS, suggesting test infrastructure works.

Current implementation:
- org-gtd-graph--get-all-gtd-tasks: Uses with-org-gtd-context + 'agenda scope
- org-gtd-graph--select-or-create-task-prioritizing-current: Uses org-gtd-get-task-projects
- Filters out project headings (ORG_GTD='Projects')
- Partitions by project membership using (member project-id project-ids)

Test Results:
- Test 1: Expects task-in-project first, gets different ID (wrong ordering)  
- Test 2: PASSES (finds external task correctly)
- Test 3: Gets nil (empty result list)

Logic appears sound but results don't match. Needs investigation into:
1. Why test 1 returns wrong ID first (partitioning issue?)
2. Why test 3 returns empty (org-map-entries not finding tasks?)
3. Possible difference in how test vs production buffers/files are handled
